Bush: This is what makes employees happy at work", "slug": "michael_c_bush_this_is_what_makes_employees_happy_at_work", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "4771", "slug": "michael_bush", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Michael C.", "lastname": "Bush", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Equity visionary", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/32e9918a025938006f3db36e558f282a6f42d79b_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Michael C. Bush is helping to build a better world by helping organizations become great places to work for all.", "whylisten": "

Michael C. Bush is CEO of Great Place to Work, the global research and analytics firm that produces the annual FORTUNE 100 Best Companies to Work For list, the 100 Best Workplaces for Women list, the Best Workplaces for Diversity list and dozens of other distinguished workplace rankings around the world.
 
Since 2015, Bush has expanded Great Place to Work's global mission to build a better world by helping organizations create great places to work not just for some but for all. Under his leadership, the firm has developed a higher standard of excellence that accounts for fair and equitable treatment of employees across demographic groups, as well as executive leader effectiveness, innovation and financial sustainability.
 
His book A Great Place to Work For All outlines the compelling business and social benefits that come from these efforts.

Bush is CEO of Great Place to Work, the global research and analytics firm that produces the annual FORTUNE 100 Best Companies to Work For list, the 100 Best Workplaces for Women list, the Best Workplaces for Diversity list and dozens of other distinguished workplace rankings around the world.

His book A Great Place to Work For All outlines the compelling business and social benefits that come from these efforts.

author: Michael C._Bush;
title: This is what makes employees happy at work

aws-transcripts.transcript: we serve a CEO. Police officers, truck drivers, cooks, engineers. If people are working, we've surveyed and what we know in terms of their happiness, workers all want the same things. There's 3,000,000,000 working people in the world, and about 40% of them would saying they're happy work. That means about one point 8,000,000,000 are almost 2,000,000,000 people are not happy at work. But what does that do both to those people and the organizations that they work in? Well, let's talk about money. Organizations that have a lot of happy employees have three times the revenue growth compared to organizations where that's not true. They outperformed stock market by a factor of three. And if you look at employee turnover, it's half that of organizations that have a lot of unhappy employees. Miracle thing is, you don't have to spend more money to make this happen. It's not about ping pong tables and massages and pet walk. It's not about the perks. It's all about how they're treated by their leaders and by the people that they work with. So I'd like to share a few ideas that create Happy Employees Idea number one in organizations where employees air happy. What you find is two things for president, trust and respect. Leaders often say. We trust our employees, we empower employees. And then when an employee needs a laptop and this is a true example, 15 people have to approve that laptop. So for the employees, all the words are right, but 15 levels of approval for a $1500 laptop. You've actually spent more money than the laptop on the approval, and the employee feels maybe they're really not trusted. So what could our organization d'oh toe have? Ah, high level of trust. The first organization that comes to mind is four seasons. They have magnificent properties all around the world, and their employees were told, Do whatever you think is right when servicing the customer toe hand that trust to your employees to do whatever they think is right makes the employees feel great. And this is why they're known for delivering some of the best service in the world. Idea number two fairness thing that erodes trust in our organization faster than anything else is when employees feel that they're being treated unfairly. Employees want to be treated the same regardless of their rank or their 10 year or their age or their experience or their job category compared to anyone else. When I think about great organizations who get fairness right, the first organization that comes to mind is Salesforce. They've found that men and women working in the same job with same level of proficiency we're making different amounts of money. So immediately they calculated the difference, and they invested $3,000,000 to try and balance things out. Idea number three is listening. So to be a listener who connects with all types of people, we have to unlearn a few things We've all been taught about active listening and eye contact, an intense stare and a compassionate look. That's not listen, repeating what the person says that's not listen, being humble and always hunting and searching for the best idea possible. That's what listening is an employee's can feel. Whether you're doing that or not. They want to know when they talk to you and Sheldon idea. Did you consider it when you made her decision? The one thing that everybody appreciates and wants when they're speaking is to know that what they say matters so much you might actually change your mind. Otherwise, what's the point of the conversation way? All know the things we need to change the things that we need to do differently. The way you behave, the way you treat others, the way you respond, the way you support defines the work experience for everyone around you. Changing to be a better person in the world is littered with those failures, but changing because there's something you believe in some purpose that you have, where you're willing to risk almost everything because it's so important to you. That's the reason to change. If it's not, you should probably find a different place to work.
